transcripts.text: Quarantine has forced many of us outside of our comfort zones in an effort to find new and innovative ways to stay entertained.  But here's one activity that statistically black folks don't take part in.  But after this story, a few of you may have a change of heart.

Look at that right there.  Look at that baby.  Come on.  Hunter is a trailblazer in the world of camping and his mission is to break the stigma that black folks don't camp and he's doing it one camping trip at a time.

Started the company because I saw a disparity of black folks in the industry.  I saw disparity of black folks in the lifestyle and I figured, listen, if I'm the only black executive in the RV industry, why not leave the industry and get more black folks to go camping and enjoy the outdoors.
And that's exactly what he spends his days doing.
Now the boy's going up a little bit hill.  See, I told him before they did this, I said, fellas, it ain't gonna be just no walk in the park.  It's gonna be like you're going You're in the Olympics.
Helping to change the face of camping from what it overwhelmingly looked like in the past.

Much like other white-only spaces carved into our history, camping was one of them.  There were very little camping sites available to black people, if there were any at all.  especially in the South, where in those same woods that those folks were camping, black folks were being lynched in.  But today, Black Folks Camp 2 isn't just about getting black folks out to camp.  It's about getting black folks out to camp with anyone, anywhere.
If I got a fortune to come out here and see this, man, I almost might twist your arm because you're missing something amazing, man.  Absolutely amazing.

Today, the outdoor recreation economy generates more than $880 billion in consumer spending, according to the Outdoor Industry Association.  In a look at other numbers, data from the National Park Service still shows a deep disparity And those who are able to access campsites, whites making up 90% of visitors to public lands, while blacks make up just over 1%.  Reasons include discrimination, cost, and historical trauma.  The company now reaching more than 2,000 black folks that can say they camp too.

And now states like Oregon are creating initiatives to help push the narrative that minorities are more than welcome in these spaces.  And they're doing it by offering free camping to people of color.  Washington and California are also among states that have included diversity in the great outdoor conversation.

Do your own camp experience, whatever you feel comfortable with.  There's so many different ways that you can approach it, whether it's in the RV, in a tent, But whatever you feel comfortable with is the most important thing to get the best experience.
